form.longName: PhenX PX810101 - Body Temperature Tympanic Thermometers
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides a description for obtaining body temperature by tympanic (i.e. ear) thermometers.

headerInstruction.text: The following is a summary description for obtaining body temperature by tympanic (i.e. ear) measurement. Tympanic Body Temperature: There are many different types of ear thermometers that are appropriate for this protocol. Investigators shou..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: If alcohol or wet wipes were used to clean the thermometer probe tip, was caution exercised when taking the reading? (scd_bodytemperaturetympanic_alcohol_wiptes)
Was the thermometer calibrated and used under manufacturer's recommendations? (scd_bodytemperaturetympanic_calibration)
Was the thermometer probe placed into the ear canal according to the manufacturer guidelines? (scd_bodytemperaturetympanic_earcanal)
Was the thermometer inspected for dirt or damage before and after use? (scd_bodytemperaturetympanic_inspection)
What is the reading from the thermometer in Fahrenheit? (scd_bodytemperaturetympanic_reading)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides a description for obtaining body temperature by tympanic (i.e. ear) thermometers.

form.preferredDefinition: The American College of Radiology - Society for Pediatric Radiology (ACR-SPR) "Practice Parameter for the Performance of Chest Radiography" Amended 2014 (Resolution 39) outlines principles for performing high-quality chest X-rays in adult and pediatric participants. Topics covered include indications and contraindications for chest X-ray, qualifications and responsibilities of personnel, specifications of the examination, documentation and reporting, equipment specifications, radiation safety in imaging, quality control and improvement, safety, infection control, and patient education.

headerInstruction.text: Chest Radiograph (i.e. Xray).The full American College of Radiology Society for Pediatric Radiology (ACRSPR) "Practice Parameter for the Performance of Chest Radiography" Amended 2014 (Resolution 39) is posted here and is also available at th..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Does the patient display cardiopulmonary signs and/or symptoms? (chestradiograph_cardiopulmonary_symptoms)
What is today's date? (chestradiograph_date)
What is the date of the patient's last menstrual cycle? (chestradiograph_date_last_menstrual_cycle)
Does the radiograph equipment have a beamlimiting device that provides rectangular collimation? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement1)
For routine upright projections, is there at least a 72inch sourceimage distance (SID) to minimize magnification? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement2)
For clinically necessary imaging (e.g. supine positioning, infants, young children, immobilized patients, etc), is there at least a 40inch SID? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement3)
Does the nominal source (focal spot) exceed 2.0mm? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement4)
Is this procedure part of an analog study? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement5)
If so, is an intensifying screen being used? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement5a)
Is a filmscreen image receptor being used? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement6)
If so, is the image processing being automated through carefully controlled temperature, densitometry and maintenance settings? (chestradiograph_equipment_requirement6a)
For adult patients, using the appropriate technical settings, does the exposed radiograph display the lung parenchyma at a midgray level? (chestradiograph_examination_adult_correct_exposure)

For newborns, infants, and children, using the appropriate technical settings, does the exposed radiograph display the lung parenchyma at a midgray level? (chestradiograph_examination_child_correct_exposure)
What is the examination date? (chestradiograph_examination_date)
Where both lung apices and the costophrenic sulci included in the radiograph images? (chestradiograph_examination_image_included)
Was an image of the erect PA projection taken? (chestradiograph_examination_image_projection1)
Was an image of a left lateral projection taken? (chestradiograph_examination_image_projection2)
If an erect PA or left lateral projection was not taken, what was the reason for the need of an alternative? (chestradiograph_examination_image_projection3)
What projections were taken as an alternative? Check all that apply (chestradiograph_examination_image_projection3a)
Was a crosstable lateral radiograph taken, where the patient was in supine position with his/her arms raised above their head? (chestradiograph_examination_position_alternative)
Are there policies and procedures for appropriate shielding of patients? (chestradiograph_examination_protocols_shielding)

Are technique charts and/or protocols in generator memory for all anatomic parts, listing exposure factors that will reliably produce diagnosticquality images of patients of different sizes available? (chestradiograph_examination_protocols_techniques)

What protocols for the standard view or views of each anatomic area of interest was used? These should be designed to optimize diagnostic information while minimizing radiation exposure (chestradiograph_examination_protocols_views)
What sort of appropriate collimation was used to limit exposure to the anatomic area of interest? (chestradiograph_examination_side)
What is the time of examination? (chestradiograph_examination_time)
What is the facility identification number? (chestradiograph_facility_id)
Does the patient need a chest radiograph to be in compliance with government regulations? (chestradiograph_government_compliance)
Is the image being processed and reviewed by the qualified professional? Is the image being procesed automated by the proprietary software? (chestradiograph_image_interpretator)

Is each film/image permanently marked with the facility identification, patient's name, identification number, right or left side indication, patient position, and the date and time of the radiographic exposure? (chestradiograph_image_metadata)
When the examination is completed, were the images reviewed by qualified personnel, either a physician or radiologic (chestradiograph_image_review)
Were the images of less than optimal diagnostic quality? (chestradiograph_image_review_not_optimal)

Does the medical physicist have certification in therapeutic medical physics, diagnostic medical physics, radiological physics, diagnostic radiological physics, and diagnostic imaging physics? (chestradiograph_medical_physicist_certification)

If no to previous question, is the medical physicist certified in any other subfield recommended by the American Board of Radiology (ABR), the Canadian College of Physics in Medicine, or by the American Board of Medical Physics (ABMP)? (chestradiograph_medical_physicist_certification_subfield)
What is the patient's age? (chestradiograph_patient_age)
Is the patient critically ill or medically unstable? (chestradiograph_patient_critically_ill)
Is it difficult to transport the patient for standard chest radiography because of his/her age or clinical condition? (chestradiograph_patient_difficulty_transporting)
If patient knows she is pregnant, what is the gestational age of the patient? (chestradiograph_patient_gestational_age)
What is the patient identification number? (chestradiograph_patient_id)
Is the patient connected to monitoring and/or lifesupport devices? (chestradiograph_patient_monitoring_lifesupport_devices)
If patient is unsure if pregnant, what is the result of the pregnancy test? (chestradiograph_patient_pregnancy_test)
Is the patient pregnant or potentially pregnant? (chestradiograph_patient_pregnant)

Is the licensed physician certified in Radiology or Diagnostic Radiology by the American Board of Radiology, the American Osteopathic Board of Radiology, the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada, or the College des Medcins du Quebec? (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_certification)

If no to previous question, has the licensed physician completed a diagnostic radiology residency program approved by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME), the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada (RCPSC), the College des Medecins du Quebec, or the American Osteopathic Association (AOA) to include radiographic training on all body areas and documentation of a minimum of 6 months of formal dedicated training in the interpretation and formal reporting of general imaging, for patients of all ages? (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_certification2)

Does the licensed physician have documented training in and understanding of the physics of diagnostic radiography and have experience with the equipment needed to safely produce the images? (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_qualification2)
Is the licensed physician familiar with the principles of radiation protection, the hazards of radiation, and radiation monitoring requirements? (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_qualification3)

Does the licensed physician have documented training and understanding of other medical imaging modalities (fluoroscopy, computed tomography, ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging, nuclear medicine, etc) and their value relative to general radiography in order to determine the best imaging examination to evaluate the patient's clinical symptoms? (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_qualification4)

Has the licensed physician performing these general radiography examinations demonstrated evidence of continued competence in the interpretation and reporting of these examinations? (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_qualification5)
Does the physician meet the last 5 requirements? If no, then physician is not qualified to perform general radiography examinations. (chestradiograph_physician_radiograph_qualified)

Does the patient require a preoperative radiographic evaluation due to cardiac or respiratory symptoms or because there is a significant potential for thoracic pathology that may influence anesthesia or the surgical result or lead to increased perioperative morbidity or mortality? (chestradiograph_preoperative_evaluation)
Which of the following best describes the individual responsible for interpeting and supervising the generation of these radiographic images? (chestradiograph_radiograph_interpreter)

Is the radiological assistant certified and registered as a radiological assistant by the American Registry of Radiologic Technologists (ARRT) after successfully completing an advanced academic program encompassing an ACR/ASRT (American Society of Radiologic Technologists) radiologist assistant curriculum and a radiologistdirected clinical preceptorship? (chestradiograph_radiological_assistant_certification)
Is the radiologic technologic certified by the American Registry of Radiologic Technologist (ARRT) or an unrestricted state licese? (chestradiograph_radiological_assistant_certification2)
Has the patient recently had cardiac or thoacic surgery or suffered from trauma? (chestradiograph_recent_medical_events)
Is there a written or electronic request for chest radiography? (chestradiograph_request)
Who was responsible for the request for radiological examination? (chestradiograph_requestor)
If sexually active, were any contraceptive methods used? (chestradiograph_sexuallyactive_contraception)
Was the patient sexually active after her last menstrual cycle? (chestradiograph_sexuallyactive_last_menstrual_cycle)
Does the patient need to be evaluated for thoracic disease processes, including systemic and extrathoracic diseases that secondarily involve the chest? (chestradiograph_signssymptoms_disease)
Does the patient need a followup of known thoracic disease processes to assess improvement, resolution, or progression? (chestradiograph_signssymptoms_disease_followup)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The American College of Radiology - Society for Pediatric Radiology (ACR-SPR) "Practice Parameter for the Performance of Chest Radiography" Amended 2014 (Resolution 39) outlines principles for performing high-quality chest X-rays in adult and pediatric participants. Topics covered include indications and contraindications for chest X-ray, qualifications and responsibilities of personnel, specifications of the examination, documentation and reporting, equipment specifications, radiation safety in imaging, quality control and improvement, safety, infection control, and patient education.

form.longName: PhenX PX810102 - Body Temperature Oral Thermometers
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides a description for obtaining body temperature by oral thermometers.

headerInstruction.text: Oral Body Temperature: There are many different types of oral thermometers that are appropriate for this protocol. Investigators should follow the manufacturer's recommendations for calibration and measurement. Place the thermometer probe in..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: Was the thermometer calibrated and used under manufacturer's recommendations? (scd_bodytemperatureoral_thermometer_calibration)
What is the reading from the thermometer? In Fahrenheit (scd_bodytemperatureoral_thermometer_reading)

protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol provides a description for obtaining body temperature by oral thermometers.

form.longName: PhenX PX810301 - Lung Function Diffusion Capacity
form.preferredDefinition: The American Thoracic Society (ATS) and the European Respiratory Society (ERS) Task Force recommendations for standardisation of the single-breath determination of carbon monoxide uptake in the lung outlines principles for performing high-quality single-breath carbon monoxide diffusing capacity (DLCO) testing. Topics covered include necessary equipment (e.g., gas analyzers), standardization issues associated with single-breath testing technique, and how to evaluate the quality of measurements of DLCO, calculations, definitions and abbreviations. These recommendations for the single-breath determination of carbon monoxide uptake in the lung are part of a series of recommendations by the ATS/ERS Task Force for the standardization of lung function testing, which can be found on the ATS website at [link[www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php|www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php]]. Detailed information regarding patient preparation is included in the general considerations section of the recommendations for lung function testing in this series.

headerInstruction.text: Lung Function Testing: Singlebreath carbon monoxide diffusing capacity (DLCO).The American Thoracic Society (ATS) and the European Respiratory Society (ERS) Task Force recommendations for standardisation of the singlebreath determination of ca..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: What is the gas concentration of the test gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_concentration_testgas)
For adults, is the dead space volume consisting of the volume from the valve, filter, and mouthpiece under 0.35 Liters? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_deadspace_adult)
What is the dead space volume measurement for the alveolar sample? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_deadspace_alveolarsample)
What is the dead space volume measurement for the inspired test gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_deadspace_volume)
How is this metric used in the datacomputation above? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_deadspace_volumemetric)
How is this metric used in the datacomputation above? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_deadspace_volumemetric2)
Does the device allow exhaled gases to cool (e.g. volume to contract)? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_device_coolgas)
Does the device remove CO2 from the exhaled gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_device_removeco2)
Does the device remove H20 from the exhaled gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_device_removeh2o)

Is the device calibrated to accurately detect the exhaled carbon monoxide and the tracer gas concentrations, which is calculated between the inhaled (test gas concentrations) and zero measurement (no CO or tracer gas present in the device)? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_calibratedaccuracy)

If so, are the deviations from the true measurement within 0.5% of the full scale? (for example, if 0.3% CO is used for the test gas, then the maximum error on any dilution should be no more than +/ 0.0015%) (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_calibrateddeviations)

Regardless of the method being used, does the device maintain the required volume accuracy, regardless of the gas mixture, direction of gas flow (e.g. inhaled or exhaled), or pulsatile flow pattern? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_calibratedvolume)
Which of the following best describes the method for measuring inspired and expired volumes over time? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_method)
Which of the following best describes the method for measuring inspired and expired volumes over time? Other (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_method_other)
Is a demandflow regulator being used on a compressed test gas cylinder? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_regulator)
If no, is the circuit resistance of the device < 1.5 cm*H20/L/s at 6 L/s flow? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_resistance)
If yes, is the circuit resistance of the device < 10cm H20 at 6L/s inspiratory flow? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_resistance2)
Is the timing device accurate to within 1% (100ms over 10s)? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_timing)
What timing technique was used for calibration and/or testing? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_equipment_timingtechnique)
Is the inspired CO around 0.3% of the collected volume? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_inspiredco)
What is the measured gas concentration of the test gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_measuredconcentration_testgas)
Is significant drift observed over the time scale of the test (~30 sec)? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_observed_drift)
Within the last 3 months, was the accuracy of the measured gas readings assessed? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_quality_accuracy)
If no, what is today's date (test date)? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_quality_accuracydate)
Was the calibration test performed with a 'standard subject' (biological control) or simulator? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_quality_calibration)
Within the last week, was the device tested to be leakfree? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_quality_leaks)
Was the volume calibration test with the 3L syringe performed? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_quality_volumecalibration)
Is the reading stable +/ 0.001% absolute for CO? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_readingstability_co)
Is the reading stable +/ 0.5% of the full scale reading for the tracer gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_readingstability_tracer)
Are carboxyhemoglobin levels < 2%? If not, needs to be considered in interpretation (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_results_carboxyhemoglobin)
Did the subject breathe supplemental oxygen for 10 min prior to this test? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization)
Was a bronchodilator used? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_broncodilator)
Was the subject involved in any exercise prior to this test? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_exercise)
If so, please describe the intensity level of the exercise. (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_exerciseintensity)
What time did the subject smoke his/her last cigarette? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_lastcigarette)
Is the sample gas volume collected between 0.51.0L? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_samplegasvolume)
Has a demonstration of the manuevers involved in the test and instructions been provided to the subject? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_subjectdemonstration)
Was the subject in a supine position prior to this test? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_supine)
If so, please provide the duration of the patient in the supine position? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_supineduration)
What length of time did the subject need for total exhalation? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_totalexhalation)
If total exhalation time > 4sec, please note the expiratory time in seconds (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_totalexhalationplus)
What type of tracer gas was used? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_tracertype)
What type of tracer gas was used? Other (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_standardization_tracertypeother)
What is the age of the subject? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_age)
What is the height of the subject? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_height)
Does the subject have obstructive airway disease? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_oad)
If so, were at least 10 minutes allowed between tests? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_oadrest)
What racial/ethnic group does the subject identify with? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_race)
Were at least 4 minutes allowed between tests? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_rest)
Did the subject remain seated during that interval? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_seated)
What is the sex of the subject? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_subject_sex)
Which of the following best describes the source of test gas? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_testgas)
Which of the following best describes the source of test gas? Other (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_testgasother)
Was the device tared to zero after the last test? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_testing_newtest)
Does the timing equipment rely on automated data computation? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_timing_automatedcomputation)
If so, how accurate is the breathhold time computation? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_timing_automatedcomputationaccuracy)
What is the measured gas concentration at zero? (singlebreath_carbonmonoxide_diffusingcapacity_zero_measurement)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The American Thoracic Society (ATS) and the European Respiratory Society (ERS) Task Force recommendations for standardisation of the single-breath determination of carbon monoxide uptake in the lung outlines principles for performing high-quality single-breath carbon monoxide diffusing capacity (DLCO) testing. Topics covered include necessary equipment (e.g., gas analyzers), standardization issues associated with single-breath testing technique, and how to evaluate the quality of measurements of DLCO, calculations, definitions and abbreviations. These recommendations for the single-breath determination of carbon monoxide uptake in the lung are part of a series of recommendations by the ATS/ERS Task Force for the standardization of lung function testing, which can be found on the ATS website at [link[www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php|www.thoracic.org/statements/pulmonary-function.php]]. Detailed information regarding patient preparation is included in the general considerations section of the recommendations for lung function testing in this series.
